tridentine_1960.name: Roman Calendar 1960 (John XXIII)
tridentine_1960.description: Roman Missal according to the 1960 rubrics before Vatican II reforms.

01-01.name: Circumcision of the Lord
01-01.description: The feast commemorating the circumcision of Jesus Christ, eight days after His birth according to Jewish law.
biography: According to the Gospel of Luke, Jesus was circumcised on the eighth day after His birth, in accordance with Jewish tradition and the Law of Moses.
This feast emphasizes Christ's submission to the Jewish Law and His full humanity, as He took on all the obligations of being human except sin.
In the traditional Roman calendar before 1970, this was a major feast celebrating Christ's first shedding of blood, prefiguring His Passion.

01-02.name: Saint Basil the Great
01-02.description: Bishop of Caesarea, Doctor of the Church, and one of the three Cappadocian Fathers.
biography: Saint Basil was born around 329 in Caesarea, Cappadocia (modern-day Turkey), into a family of saints including his grandmother Macrina the Elder, his sister Macrina the Younger, and his brothers Gregory of Nyssa and Peter of Sebaste.
After studying in Constantinople and Athens, where he befriended Gregory of Nazianzus, Basil lived as a hermit before being ordained a priest and later becoming Bishop of Caesarea in 370.

He is renowned for his theological works defending orthodox Christianity against Arianism, his rule for monastic life (still followed in Eastern monasticism), and his practical charity, including establishing hospitals and care centers for the poor.

01-03.name: Most Holy Name of Jesus
01-03.description: Feast honoring the sacred name of Jesus Christ.
biography: The devotion to the Holy Name of Jesus has ancient roots but was particularly promoted by Saint Bernardine of Siena and the Franciscan Order in the 15th century.
The name 'Jesus' means 'God saves' in Hebrew (Yeshua), and was given to the Christ child by divine command through the angel Gabriel.
This feast celebrates the power and dignity of Christ's name, which according to Scripture, is 'the name above every name' (Philippians 2:9-11).

01-04.name: Saint Elizabeth Ann Seton
01-04.description: First native-born American saint, founder of Catholic schools in the United States.
biography: Elizabeth Ann Bayley was born in New York City in 1774 into a prominent Episcopal family. She married William Seton and had five children.
After her husband's death in 1803, Elizabeth converted to Catholicism in 1805, facing significant opposition from her family and society.

She founded the Sisters of Charity of Saint Joseph in 1809, establishing the first free Catholic school in America in Emmitsburg, Maryland, and laying the foundation for Catholic education in the United States.

01-05.name: Saint John Neumann
01-05.description: Bishop of Philadelphia, founder of Catholic schools, first American male saint.
biography: John Neumann was born in Bohemia (Czech Republic) in 1811 and came to America as a missionary priest in 1836.
He joined the Redemptorist Order and became the fourth Bishop of Philadelphia in 1852, where he organized the first diocesan Catholic school system in America.
He was known for his humility, pastoral care, and dedication to education, writing catechisms and personally visiting parishes throughout his diocese despite its vast size.

01-06.name: Epiphany of the Lord
01-06.description: The manifestation of Christ to the Gentiles, represented by the Magi.
biography: The Epiphany celebrates the visit of the Magi (Wise Men) to the infant Jesus, as recorded in the Gospel of Matthew.
The word 'epiphany' means 'manifestation' or 'showing forth,' and this feast celebrates Christ being revealed to the nations beyond Israel.
Traditionally, the three gifts of gold, frankincense, and myrrh symbolize Christ's kingship, divinity, and future death and burial.

01-07.name: Saint Raymond of Penyafort
01-07.description: Dominican priest, canon lawyer, and confessor to popes.
biography: Raymond was born in Catalonia, Spain, around 1175 and became an expert in canon and civil law.
He joined the Dominican Order at age 47 and was appointed confessor to Pope Gregory IX, who commissioned him to compile the Church's decrees and canons.
His compilation, the Decretals, became the standard collection of canon law for over 700 years. He also worked for the conversion of Muslims and Jews in Spain.

01-08.name: Saint Apollinaris of Hierapolis
biography: Apollinaris was a 2nd-century bishop of Hierapolis in Phrygia (modern-day Turkey) and an important early Christian apologist.
He wrote defenses of Christianity addressed to Roman Emperor Marcus Aurelius and various treatises against heresies, though most of his works have been lost.
He is remembered as a defender of the faith during a time of persecution and intellectual challenges to Christianity.

01-09.name: Saint Adrian of Canterbury
01-09.description: African-born abbot and scholar in Anglo-Saxon England.
biography: Adrian was born in North Africa and became an abbot near Naples. Pope Vitalian twice offered him the See of Canterbury, but he declined.
He accompanied Theodore of Tarsus to England in 669 and became Abbot of St. Augustine's Abbey in Canterbury.
Adrian was renowned for his scholarship in Scripture, theology, poetry, and astronomy, and his school at Canterbury became one of the most important centers of learning in England.

01-10.name: Saint William of Bourges
01-10.description: Archbishop known for his austere life and care for the poor.
biography: William was born into a noble family in Nevers, France, in 1120. Despite his family's wishes, he became a Cistercian monk.
He was appointed Archbishop of Bourges in 1200 and was known for his personal austerity, living in a small cell and giving everything to the poor.
He worked tirelessly to reform the clergy and defend the Church's rights while caring for the spiritual and material needs of his flock.

01-11.name: Saint Hyginus
01-11.description: Pope and martyr in the 2nd century.
biography: Hyginus was a Greek philosopher who converted to Christianity and was elected Pope around 138 AD.
He served during the reigns of Emperors Hadrian and Antoninus Pius, a period of sporadic persecution of Christians.
Though details of his pontificate are scarce, tradition holds that he was martyred for the faith around 142 AD. He is buried near Saint Peter in the Vatican.

01-12.name: Saint Arcadius
01-12.description: Martyr in Mauritania during Diocletian's persecution.
biography: Arcadius was a Christian living in Mauritania (North Africa) during the reign of Emperor Diocletian.
When persecution began, he chose to remain in his region to strengthen other Christians rather than flee.

He was arrested and subjected to a unique torture: his limbs were cut off one by one over several days, during which he continued to praise God and encourage onlookers, until he finally died from his wounds.

01-13.name: Saint Hilary of Poitiers
01-13.description: Bishop, Doctor of the Church, and defender of orthodoxy against Arianism.
biography: Hilary was born around 315 in Poitiers, France, to a pagan family. Through philosophical inquiry, he came to believe in Christianity and was baptized as an adult.
He was chosen as Bishop of Poitiers around 353 and became a leading opponent of Arianism, which denied Christ's divinity. He was exiled for four years but continued writing theological works.
His major work, 'On the Trinity,' is one of the earliest and most important Latin theological treatises. He is considered the 'Athanasius of the West' for his defense of Nicene orthodoxy.

01-14.name: Saint Felix of Nola
01-14.description: Priest and confessor during Diocletian persecution.
biography: Felix was a priest in Nola, Italy, during the persecution under Emperor Decius (250 AD).
When his bishop, Maximus, was arrested, Felix took over leadership of the community. He was arrested, tortured, and miraculously freed by an angel.
Felix spent the rest of his life hiding, ministering to Christians in secret, and living in poverty. He survived the persecution and died peacefully around 260 AD.

01-15.name: Saint Paul the Hermit
01-15.description: First Christian hermit, lived in the Egyptian desert.
biography: Paul was born around 227 in Egypt. During the Decian persecution, he fled to the desert and chose to remain there as a hermit.
He lived in a cave for over 90 years, sustained by a palm tree and half a loaf of bread brought daily by a raven.
Saint Anthony the Great visited him shortly before his death around 342. Paul is considered the first Christian hermit, predating Anthony's desert monasticism.

01-16.name: Saint Marcellus I
01-16.description: Pope and confessor who reorganized the Church after persecution.
biography: Marcellus became Pope around 308, after the See of Peter had been vacant for four years following the persecution of Diocletian.
He worked to reorganize the Church, establishing 25 'titles' or parishes in Rome and addressing the question of how to receive back those who had lapsed during persecution.
His stance that lapsed Christians should do severe penance before being readmitted angered some, leading to riots. He was banished by Emperor Maxentius and died in exile around 309.

01-17.name: Saint Anthony the Great
01-17.description: Father of monasticism, hermit in the Egyptian desert.
biography: Anthony was born in Egypt around 251 to wealthy Christian parents. At age 20, inspired by Christ's words to the rich young man, he gave away his inheritance and went to live as a hermit.
He spent 20 years in complete solitude in the desert, facing and overcoming severe temptations from demons, which became a famous theme in Christian art.
Later, disciples gathered around him, and he organized them into a loose community, making him the father of Christian monasticism. He lived to be 105, dying around 356.

01-18.name: Chair of Saint Peter at Rome
01-18.description: Feast commemorating the authority of Peter as the first Bishop of Rome.
biography: This feast celebrates the authority given by Christ to Saint Peter as the rock upon which He would build His Church.
The 'chair' symbolizes the teaching authority (magisterium) of the successor of Peter, the Bishop of Rome.
This feast has been celebrated since ancient times, though it was moved to February 22 after the liturgical reforms of 1960.

01-19.name: Saints Marius, Martha, Audifax, and Abachum
biography: Marius and Martha were a Persian couple who, with their sons Audifax and Abachum, came to Rome around 270 AD to venerate the tombs of the martyrs.
They devoted themselves to burying the bodies of martyred Christians during the persecution under Emperor Claudius II.
They were arrested for this charitable work and executed around 270 AD, becoming martyrs themselves.

01-20.name: Saints Fabian and Sebastian
01-20.description: Pope and martyr (Fabian); Roman soldier and martyr (Sebastian).
biography: Fabian was elected Pope in 236 in an unexpected way: a dove descended on his head during the election. He served for 14 years, organizing the Roman Church and promoting missionary work.
He was martyred in 250 during the persecution of Emperor Decius. His tomb has been found in the catacombs of Rome.
Sebastian was a Roman soldier and secret Christian who encouraged imprisoned Christians. When discovered, he was tied to a tree and shot with arrows. He survived but was later clubbed to death.
patronage: Sebastian: Athletes, soldiers, plague victims; Fabian: Potters, lead workers

01-21.name: Saint Agnes
01-21.description: Virgin and martyr, died at age 13 in Rome.
biography: Agnes was a beautiful Roman girl from a noble family who consecrated her virginity to God at age 12.
When she rejected the advances of a pagan nobleman's son, she was denounced as a Christian and brought before the prefect.
Despite her youth, she boldly professed her faith. Various tortures failed to break her resolve, and she was finally martyred around 304 AD during Diocletian's persecution.

01-22.name: Saints Vincent and Anastasius
01-22.description: Vincent: Deacon and martyr in Spain; Anastasius: Persian monk and martyr.
biography: Vincent was a deacon in Zaragoza, Spain, under Bishop Valerius. During Diocletian's persecution (304 AD), both were arrested.
Vincent was subjected to brutal tortures including being stretched on the rack, burned with hot metal, and thrown on broken pottery, but he remained faithful unto death.
Anastasius was a Persian soldier who converted to Christianity, became a monk, and was martyred in 628 AD during the Persian persecution.
patronage: Vincent: Winegrowers, vinegar makers; Anastasius: Against headaches

01-23.name: Saint Raymond of Penyafort
biography: Raymond was born in Catalonia around 1175 and became a renowned professor of law.
He joined the Dominicans at age 47 and became confessor to Pope Gregory IX, who commissioned him to compile canon law.
He also worked for the conversion of Moors and Jews in Spain and promoted the study of Arabic and Hebrew among Dominicans.

01-24.name: Saint Timothy
01-24.description: Bishop of Ephesus, companion of Saint Paul.
biography: Timothy was the son of a Greek father and a Jewish-Christian mother, Eunice. He became a companion of Saint Paul during his missionary journeys.
Paul entrusted him with important missions and wrote two epistles to him that are part of the New Testament.
He became the first Bishop of Ephesus and was martyred around 97 AD while opposing a pagan festival.

01-25.name: Conversion of Saint Paul
01-25.description: Commemoration of Paul's conversion on the road to Damascus.
biography: Saul of Tarsus was a zealous Pharisee who persecuted early Christians until his dramatic conversion around 34 AD.
While traveling to Damascus to arrest Christians, he was struck by a blinding light and heard the voice of Jesus asking, 'Saul, why do you persecute me?'
Blinded for three days, he was baptized by Ananias and became Paul, the great Apostle to the Gentiles, writing much of the New Testament.

01-26.name: Saint Polycarp
01-26.description: Bishop of Smyrna, disciple of Saint John, martyr.
biography: Polycarp was born around 69 AD and became a disciple of Saint John the Apostle, forming a direct link to Christ's original followers.
He served as Bishop of Smyrna (modern Izmir, Turkey) and was a key figure in early Christianity, fighting against Gnostic heresies.
At age 86, he was martyred by being burned at the stake around 155 AD. His final words were: 'Eighty-six years I have served Him, and He has done me no wrong.'

01-27.name: Translation of Saint John Chrysostom
01-27.description: Transfer of relics of the great preacher and Doctor of the Church.
biography: This feast commemorates the transfer of Saint John Chrysostom's relics to Constantinople in 438 AD.
John Chrysostom (347-407) was Archbishop of Constantinople, known for his eloquent preaching (Chrysostom means 'golden-mouthed').
He was exiled twice for criticizing the imperial family and died in exile, but was later recognized as one of the greatest Church Fathers.

01-28.name: Saint Peter Nolasco
01-28.description: Founder of the Mercedarian Order for ransoming captives.
biography: Peter was born in Barcelona around 1180. Moved by the plight of Christians captured by Moors, he devoted his fortune to ransoming them.
In 1218, he founded the Order of Our Lady of Mercy (Mercedarians) with Saint Raymond of Penyafort, dedicated to freeing Christian captives.
The order ransomed thousands of captives during the centuries of conflict between Christians and Muslims in Spain and North Africa.

01-29.name: Saint Francis de Sales
01-29.description: Bishop of Geneva, Doctor of the Church, master of spirituality.
biography: Francis was born in Savoy in 1567 to a noble family. Despite his father's plans for a legal career, he became a priest and then Bishop of Geneva.
He worked tirelessly to convert Calvinists back to Catholicism, eventually reconverting tens of thousands through his gentle approach.
He wrote 'Introduction to the Devout Life' and 'Treatise on the Love of God,' making spirituality accessible to laypeople. With Saint Jane de Chantal, he founded the Order of the Visitation.

01-30.name: Saint Martina
biography: Martina was a Roman virgin of noble birth who lived during the reign of Emperor Alexander Severus (3rd century).
After her parents' death, she distributed her wealth to the poor and devoted herself to prayer and serving the Church.
She was arrested during a persecution, refused to sacrifice to pagan gods, and was martyred after various tortures including wild beasts and fire failed to harm her.

01-31.name: Saint John Bosco
01-31.description: Priest, founder of the Salesians, apostle to youth.
biography: John Bosco was born in poverty in Piedmont, Italy, in 1815. Despite hardships, he became a priest in 1841.
He dedicated his life to educating and caring for poor and abandoned boys in Turin, founding the Salesian Society in 1859.
His 'preventive system' of education emphasized reason, religion, and kindness rather than punishment. He also founded the Daughters of Mary Help of Christians with Saint Mary Mazzarello.

02-01.name: Saint Ignatius of Antioch
02-01.description: Bishop and martyr, Father of the Church.
biography: Ignatius was the third Bishop of Antioch, succeeding Saint Peter and Saint Evodius around 69 AD.
He was arrested during the persecution of Emperor Trajan and sent to Rome to be martyred around 107 AD.
During his journey to Rome, he wrote seven letters to various churches, which are among the earliest Christian writings outside the New Testament. He was thrown to wild beasts in the Colosseum.
patronage: Church in North Africa and Eastern Mediterranean

02-02.name: Purification of the Blessed Virgin Mary (Candlemas)
02-02.description: Feast commemorating Mary's purification and Jesus' presentation in the Temple.
biography: Forty days after the birth of Jesus, Mary and Joseph brought Him to the Temple in Jerusalem to present Him to the Lord, according to Jewish law.
There they encountered Simeon, who recognized Jesus as the Messiah, and Anna the prophetess.
This feast is also known as Candlemas because candles are blessed on this day, symbolizing Christ as the Light of the World.

02-03.name: Saint Blaise
02-03.description: Bishop and martyr, patron of throat ailments.
biography: Blaise was Bishop of Sebastea in Armenia during the early 4th century.
According to tradition, while imprisoned for his faith, he miraculously cured a boy who was choking on a fishbone.
He was martyred around 316 AD during the persecution of Emperor Licinius. The blessing of throats on his feast day is a popular devotion.

02-04.name: Saint Andrew Corsini
biography: Andrew Corsini was born in Florence in 1302 to a noble family. After a worldly youth, he converted and joined the Carmelites.
He became Bishop of Fiesole in 1349 and was known for his holiness, charity to the poor, and successful diplomatic missions to restore peace.
He died in 1373 and was canonized in 1629.

02-05.name: Saint Agatha
biography: Agatha was a beautiful Christian virgin from a noble family in Sicily, living in the 3rd century.
She rejected the advances of the Roman prefect Quintianus, who had her arrested and tortured.
Her tortures included having her breasts cut off. She died in prison around 251 AD. She is invoked against fire and earthquakes.

02-06.name: Saint Titus
02-06.description: Bishop of Crete, companion of Saint Paul.
biography: Titus was a Greek convert who became a trusted companion and co-worker of Saint Paul.
Paul left him in Crete to organize the Church there and ordained him as the first Bishop of Crete.
The Epistle to Titus in the New Testament was written by Paul to give him instructions for Church governance. He is believed to have died around 96 AD.

02-07.name: Saint Romuald
biography: Romuald was born in Ravenna, Italy, around 951. After witnessing his father kill a relative in a duel, he entered a Benedictine monastery in penance.
Seeking a more austere life, he became a hermit and eventually founded the Camaldolese Order, which combines eremitical and cenobitic monasticism.
He established numerous hermitages and monasteries throughout Italy. He died in 1027.

02-08.name: Saint John of Matha
02-08.description: Founder of the Trinitarian Order for ransoming captives.
biography: John of Matha was born in Provence, France, in 1160. He studied theology in Paris and was ordained a priest.
During his first Mass, he had a vision that inspired him to found the Order of the Most Holy Trinity (Trinitarians) in 1198, dedicated to ransoming Christian captives from Muslims.
He personally traveled to North Africa to redeem captives and died in Rome in 1213.
attributes: Trinitarian habit with red and blue cross

02-09.name: Saint Cyril of Alexandria
02-09.description: Bishop, Doctor of the Church, defender of Mary as Mother of God.
biography: Cyril became Patriarch of Alexandria in 412 AD and was a brilliant theologian and fierce defender of orthodox Christianity.
He is best known for his role in the Council of Ephesus (431 AD), where he successfully defended the title 'Theotokos' (Mother of God) for Mary against Nestorius.
He wrote extensively against heresies and in defense of the unity of Christ's divine and human natures. He died in 444 AD.

02-10.name: Saint Scholastica
02-10.description: Sister of Saint Benedict, patroness of Benedictine nuns.
biography: Scholastica was the twin sister of Saint Benedict of Nursia, born around 480 in Nursia, Italy.
She consecrated her life to God from an early age and founded a monastery near Monte Cassino, where Benedict had his famous monastery.
She and Benedict met once a year to discuss spiritual matters. At their last meeting, she prayed for a storm to keep him longer. She died three days later around 543 AD.

02-11.name: Our Lady of Lourdes
02-11.description: Apparition of the Blessed Virgin Mary to Saint Bernadette.
biography: On February 11, 1858, the Blessed Virgin Mary appeared to Bernadette Soubirous, a 14-year-old peasant girl, in Lourdes, France.
Over the course of 18 apparitions, Mary identified herself as the 'Immaculate Conception' and revealed a spring whose waters have been associated with numerous miraculous healings.
Lourdes has become one of the most important pilgrimage sites in the Catholic world, particularly for the sick and disabled.
attributes: Mary in white with blue sash

02-12.name: Seven Holy Founders of the Servite Order
02-12.description: Seven Florentine merchants who founded the Servite Order.
biography: In 1233, seven wealthy merchants in Florence left their businesses to dedicate themselves to prayer and penance, forming a community devoted to the Blessed Virgin Mary.
They founded the Order of Servants of Mary (Servites), emphasizing contemplation and service to the poor.
The seven founders were: Bonfilius, Alexis, Manettus, Amideus, Hugh, Sosteneus, and Buonagiunta. They died between 1262 and 1310 and were canonized together in 1887.

02-13.name: Saint Catherine de' Ricci
02-13.description: Dominican mystic known for ecstasies and visions of the Passion.
biography: Catherine was born in Florence in 1522 and entered the Dominican convent in Prato at age 13.
She became prioress and was known for her mystical experiences, particularly weekly ecstasies reliving Christ's Passion from Thursday to Friday.
She bore the stigmata and corresponded with important religious figures including Saint Philip Neri and Saint Charles Borromeo. She died in 1590.

02-14.name: Saint Valentine
02-14.description: Priest and martyr, patron of lovers.
biography: Saint Valentine was a priest in Rome during the 3rd century under Emperor Claudius II. The emperor had banned marriages for young men, believing single men made better soldiers.
Valentine defied this decree and continued to perform marriages for young lovers in secret. When his actions were discovered, he was imprisoned.
While in prison, he healed the blind daughter of his jailer and wrote her a farewell message signed 'Your Valentine.' He was executed on February 14, around 269 AD.

02-15.name: Saints Faustinus and Jovita
biography: Faustinus and Jovita were brothers from a noble family in Brescia, Italy, during the 2nd century.
They were converted to Christianity and became priests, preaching the Gospel with great zeal.
During the persecution of Emperor Hadrian around 120 AD, they were arrested and subjected to various tortures, but remained faithful and were eventually beheaded.

02-16.name: Saints Elias, Jeremiah, Isaias, Samuel and Daniel
biography: These five Egyptian Christians went to Caesarea in Palestine to comfort Christian prisoners during the persecution of Emperor Diocletian around 309 AD.
They were arrested for visiting the prisoners and brought before the governor Firmilian.
After refusing to sacrifice to pagan gods, they were tortured and beheaded. Their bodies were thrown to wild beasts but were recovered and buried by Christians.

02-17.name: The Seven Servite Founders
02-17.description: Commemoration of the Seven Holy Founders of the Servite Order.
biography: This date commemorates the Seven Holy Founders of the Servite Order who were originally venerated on this date before the feast was moved.
These seven Florentine merchants abandoned their worldly pursuits in 1233 to form a religious community dedicated to Mary.
They lived as hermits on Monte Senario and later founded the Order of Servants of Mary (Servites).

02-18.name: Saint Simeon of Jerusalem
02-18.description: Bishop of Jerusalem, cousin of Jesus, martyr.
biography: Simeon was the son of Clopas (brother of Saint Joseph) and Mary, making him a cousin of Jesus.
He became the second Bishop of Jerusalem after Saint James the Less around 62 AD and led the Jerusalem church for many years.
He was martyred during the persecution of Emperor Trajan around 107 AD at the age of 120, being crucified like his divine cousin.

02-19.name: Seven Holy Founders of the Servite Order
02-19.description: Commemoration of the founders of the Servites.
biography: The Seven Holy Founders (Bonfilius, Alexis, Manettus, Amideus, Hugh, Sosteneus, and Buonagiunta) were wealthy Florentine merchants.
On the feast of the Assumption in 1233, they experienced a vision of the Blessed Virgin Mary calling them to a life of penance.
They withdrew to Monte Senario and founded the Order of Servants of Mary, dedicated to contemplating Mary's sorrows and serving the poor.

02-20.name: Saint Eucherius of Orleans
biography: Eucherius was born into a noble Frankish family around 687. Despite family pressure, he became a monk at Jumiges Abbey.
He was appointed Bishop of Orleans around 721 but continued to live a monastic life of prayer and poverty.
He was briefly exiled by Charles Martel for opposing his secularization of Church property but was later restored. He died around 743.

02-21.name: Saint Severian
biography: Severian was Bishop of Sebaste in Armenia during the early 4th century.
He worked to spread Christianity in Armenia and strengthen the faith of converts during a time of persecution.
He was martyred around 320 AD during the persecution under Emperor Licinius, along with forty other Christians.

02-22.name: Chair of Saint Peter
02-22.description: Feast celebrating the authority of Saint Peter and his successors.
biography: This ancient feast celebrates the teaching authority (magisterium) given by Christ to Saint Peter and his successors, the popes.
The 'chair' symbolizes the office of bishop and teacher. Peter's chair represents the unique authority Christ gave him as rock of the Church.
This feast was celebrated in Rome since at least the 4th century, honoring both Peter's Roman episcopate and his universal pastoral role.

02-23.name: Saint Peter Damian
02-23.description: Bishop, Doctor of the Church, reformer.
biography: Peter Damian was born in Ravenna, Italy, in 1007. Orphaned young and initially mistreated by his brother, he was later educated by another brother.
He became a Benedictine hermit at Fonte Avellana and was renowned for his learning and holiness. He was made Cardinal-Bishop of Ostia in 1057.
He worked tirelessly for Church reform, combating simony and clerical immorality. He was also a great spiritual writer. He died in 1072.

02-24.name: Saint Matthias the Apostle
02-24.description: Apostle chosen to replace Judas Iscariot.
biography: Matthias was one of the seventy-two disciples of Jesus and a faithful follower from the beginning of His ministry.
After Judas's betrayal and death, the eleven remaining apostles cast lots to choose his replacement, and Matthias was selected (Acts 1:15-26).
According to tradition, he preached in Judea and was martyred either by stoning and beheading or by crucifixion.

02-25.name: Saint Tarasius
02-25.description: Patriarch of Constantinople, defender of sacred images.
biography: Tarasius was a high-ranking civil servant in Constantinople when he was chosen to become Patriarch in 784, despite being a layman.
He was quickly ordained and became Patriarch, presiding over the Second Council of Nicaea (787) which condemned iconoclasm and affirmed the veneration of sacred images.
He faced opposition from iconoclasts but remained firm in defense of orthodox teaching. He died in 806.

02-26.name: Saint Alexander of Alexandria
02-26.description: Patriarch of Alexandria, opponent of Arianism.
biography: Alexander became Patriarch of Alexandria around 313 and played a crucial role in the early Church's fight against Arianism.
He excommunicated Arius for denying the divinity of Christ and worked to unite the Church against this heresy.
He attended the Council of Nicaea (325) which condemned Arianism. His deacon and successor was Saint Athanasius. He died in 328.

02-27.name: Saint Gabriel of Our Lady of Sorrows
biography: Gabriel was born Francesco Possenti in Assisi in 1838. As a young man, he was worldly and vain but experienced a conversion.
He joined the Passionist Congregation in 1856, taking the name Gabriel of Our Lady of Sorrows.
Despite suffering from tuberculosis, he lived his religious life with great joy and devotion to Mary. He died in 1862 at age 24 and was canonized in 1920.

02-28.name: Saint Romanus of Condat
02-28.description: Founder of monasteries in the Jura Mountains.
biography: Romanus was born in Burgundy around 390. Seeking solitude, he became a hermit in the Jura Mountains.
He was later joined by his brother Lupicinus and others, and together they founded the monasteries of Condat and Leuconne.
These monasteries followed a strict rule and became important centers of monasticism in Gaul. Romanus died around 460.

02-29.name: Saint Augustus Chapdelaine
02-29.description: French missionary and martyr in China.
biography: Augustus Chapdelaine was born in France in 1814 and became a priest of the Paris Foreign Missions Society.
He volunteered for the missions in China and worked there evangelizing despite the dangers of persecution.
In 1856, he was arrested, tortured, and martyred during an anti-Christian persecution. He was canonized in 2000 as one of the Martyrs of China.

03-01.name: Saint Albinus of Angers
biography: Albinus (also known as Aubin) was born around 469 in Brittany, France.
He became a monk and later abbot of Tincillacum monastery, where he was known for his holiness and learning.
He was chosen as Bishop of Angers around 529 and served with great pastoral care until his death around 554.

03-02.name: Saint Chad (Ceadda)
03-02.description: Bishop of Lichfield, missionary to Anglo-Saxons.
biography: Chad was one of four saintly brothers from Northumbria, educated at Lindisfarne under Saint Aidan.
He became abbot of Lastingham and later Bishop of York, though he humbly accepted being replaced by Saint Wilfrid.
He was then made Bishop of Lichfield in 669 by Saint Theodore of Canterbury and evangelized Mercia until his death in 672.

03-03.name: Saints Marinus and Asterius
biography: Marinus was a Roman soldier in Caesarea, Palestine, around 260 AD who was denounced as a Christian.
When offered the choice between his military position and his faith, he chose Christ and was beheaded.
Asterius, a Roman senator, claimed Marinus's body and buried it with honor, for which he was also martyred.

03-04.name: Saint Casimir
03-04.description: Polish prince, patron of Poland and Lithuania.
biography: Casimir was born in 1458, son of King Casimir IV of Poland. From youth, he was devoted to prayer and penance.
Despite pressure to marry, he remained celibate, dedicating his life to God and works of charity.
He died of tuberculosis in 1484 at age 25. He is patron saint of Poland and Lithuania.

03-05.name: Saint John Joseph of the Cross
biography: John Joseph was born on the island of Ischia, Italy, in 1654. He joined the Franciscan Alcantarines at age 16.
He lived a life of extreme penance and contemplation, experiencing mystical gifts including levitation and visions.
He served as superior of various convents and was known for his wisdom and holiness. He died in Naples in 1734.

03-06.name: Saints Perpetua and Felicity
03-06.description: Martyrs of Carthage, patron saints of mothers and expectant parents.
biography: Perpetua was a 22-year-old noblewoman and Felicity was her slave, both nursing mothers arrested in Carthage around 203 AD.
Despite family pressure, they refused to renounce their faith. Perpetua's diary, written in prison, is one of the earliest Christian writings by a woman.
They were thrown to wild beasts in the arena and then killed by sword. Their martyrdom is recounted in the famous 'Passion of Saints Perpetua and Felicity.'

03-07.name: Saint Thomas Aquinas
03-07.description: Dominican priest, Doctor of the Church, the 'Angelic Doctor.'
biography: Thomas was born near Aquino, Italy, around 1225. Despite family opposition, he joined the Dominicans at age 19.
He became the greatest theologian of the Middle Ages, writing the monumental 'Summa Theologica' and numerous other works that synthesized Christian theology with Aristotelian philosophy.
He taught at Paris and other universities. He died in 1274 on his way to the Council of Lyon and was declared a Doctor of the Church in 1567.

03-08.name: Saint John of God
03-08.description: Founder of the Hospitaller Order, patron of hospitals and the sick.
biography: John was born in Portugal in 1495. After a dissolute youth as a soldier and shepherd, he experienced a dramatic conversion around age 40.
He dedicated himself to caring for the sick and poor in Granada, Spain, founding a hospital and the Brothers Hospitallers.
His revolutionary approach to treating the mentally ill with compassion rather than chains transformed hospital care. He died in 1550.

03-09.name: Saint Frances of Rome
03-09.description: Wife, mother, mystic, and founder of the Oblates of Mary.
biography: Frances was born in Rome in 1384 to a noble family. At age 12, she was married to Lorenzo Ponziani, a wealthy nobleman.
She balanced family duties with intense prayer and service to the poor. After raising her children, she founded the Oblates of Mary.
She experienced mystical visions and was often accompanied by her guardian angel, whom she could see. She died in 1440.

03-10.name: Forty Martyrs of Sebaste
biography: These forty Roman soldiers of the Thundering Legion were stationed in Sebaste, Armenia, around 320 AD.
When they refused to offer sacrifice to pagan gods, they were sentenced to stand naked on a frozen pond overnight.
To tempt them, warm baths were prepared nearby. All but one persevered; when one soldier weakened and left, a guard was converted and took his place, keeping the number at forty.

03-11.name: Saint Constantine
03-11.description: King of Cornwall, monk and martyr.
biography: Constantine was a 6th-century king in Cornwall who, after the death of his wife, abdicated and became a monk.
He studied in Ireland under Saint Columba and then returned to evangelize Scotland.
According to tradition, he was martyred by pirates while preaching in Scotland around 576.

03-12.name: Saint Gregory the Great
03-12.description: Pope, Doctor of the Church, reformer of liturgy.
biography: Gregory was born in Rome around 540 to a noble family. He served as Prefect of Rome but left to become a Benedictine monk.
Elected Pope in 590, he reformed Church administration, liturgy (Gregorian chant), and sent Saint Augustine to evangelize England.
He wrote extensively including the 'Pastoral Rule,' 'Dialogues,' and commentaries on Scripture. He died in 604.

03-13.name: Saint Euphrasia
biography: Euphrasia was born around 380 to a noble family related to Emperor Theodosius. After her father's death, she and her mother went to Egypt.
At age seven, she entered a convent and embraced a life of extreme asceticism and obedience.
She performed the most menial tasks with joy and lived in constant prayer. She died around 410 at age 30.

03-14.name: Saint Matilda
03-14.description: Queen of Germany, known for charity and founding monasteries.
biography: Matilda was born around 895 and married Henry the Fowler, who became King of Germany in 919.
She was known for her piety, charity to the poor, and for founding numerous churches and monasteries.
After Henry's death, she faced persecution from her sons but bore it with patience. She died around 968.
attributes: Bag of coins for the poor

03-15.name: Saint Clement Mary Hofbauer
biography: Clement was born in Moravia in 1751. After working as a baker and hermit, he was ordained a priest and joined the Redemptorists.
He established the Redemptorist order north of the Alps, founding communities in Poland and working among the poor.
Expelled from Poland, he worked in Vienna, becoming a renowned preacher and confessor. He died in 1820.

03-16.name: Saints Hilary and Tatian
biography: Hilary and Tatian were early Christian martyrs, though historical details about them are limited.
They gave their lives for the faith during one of the early persecutions of the Church.
They are commemorated in the traditional Roman Martyrology for their witness to Christ.

03-17.name: Saint Patrick
biography: Patrick was born in Roman Britain around 385 AD. At age 16, he was captured by Irish raiders and taken to Ireland as a slave, where he worked as a shepherd for six years.
During his captivity, he turned to prayer and deepened his faith. After escaping and returning home, he studied for the priesthood and felt called to return to Ireland as a missionary.
As bishop, Patrick traveled throughout Ireland, baptizing thousands, ordaining priests, and establishing monasteries. He famously used the shamrock to explain the Holy Trinity. He died around 461 AD.

03-18.name: Saint Cyril of Jerusalem
03-18.description: Bishop, Doctor of the Church, catechist.
biography: Cyril was born in Jerusalem around 315 and became Bishop of Jerusalem around 350.
He is best known for his 'Catechetical Lectures,' a series of instructions for those preparing for baptism, which are masterpieces of early Christian teaching.
He suffered three exiles for defending orthodox Christianity against Arianism. He attended the Council of Constantinople in 381 and died around 386.

03-19.name: Saint Joseph, Spouse of the Blessed Virgin Mary
03-19.description: Foster father of Jesus, patron of the universal Church.
biography: Joseph was a carpenter from Nazareth, betrothed to Mary when the angel announced she would bear the Messiah. He acted with justice and mercy, protecting Mary and Jesus.
He received divine guidance through dreams, leading the Holy Family to Egypt to escape Herod's persecution and later returning to settle in Nazareth.

As the foster father of Jesus, Joseph provided for and protected the Holy Family. He taught Jesus his trade and raised Him in the Jewish faith. He is the patron of fathers, workers, and the universal Church.

03-20.name: Saint Wulfram
biography: Wulfram was a Benedictine monk who became Archbishop of Sens, France, around 682.
He resigned his see to become a missionary to the Frisians (in what is now the Netherlands).
He preached against paganism and worked many miracles. He died around 720.

03-21.name: Saint Benedict of Nursia
03-21.description: Abbot, founder of Western monasticism, patron of Europe.
biography: Benedict was born in Nursia, Italy, around 480. Disgusted by the immorality of Rome, he became a hermit in a cave at Subiaco.
Disciples gathered around him, and he founded twelve monasteries. He later established the great monastery of Monte Cassino around 529.
He wrote the Rule of Saint Benedict, which became the foundation of Western monasticism, emphasizing prayer, work, and community life. He died around 547.

03-22.name: Saint Lea
biography: Lea was a Roman widow of noble birth who lived in the 4th century.
After her husband's death, she joined a community of consecrated virgins and widows in Rome.
Saint Jerome, who knew her, praised her humility and devotion. She died around 384.

03-23.name: Saint Turibius of Mogrovejo
03-23.description: Archbishop of Lima, reformer of the Church in South America.
biography: Turibius was born in Spain in 1538. Though a layman and law professor, he was chosen to be Archbishop of Lima, Peru.
He was ordained and went to Peru, where he worked tirelessly to reform abuses, defend the rights of indigenous peoples, and evangelize.
He traveled extensively throughout his vast archdiocese, confirming over half a million people. He died in 1606.

03-24.name: Saint Gabriel the Archangel
biography: Gabriel is one of the three archangels mentioned by name in Scripture (with Michael and Raphael).
He announced the birth of John the Baptist to Zechariah and, most importantly, the Incarnation to the Virgin Mary (the Annunciation).
His name means 'God is my strength.' He is the patron of messengers and communication workers.

03-25.name: Annunciation of the Blessed Virgin Mary
03-25.description: The angel Gabriel announces to Mary that she will bear the Son of God.
biography: The Annunciation marks the moment when the Archangel Gabriel appeared to the Virgin Mary in Nazareth and announced that she would conceive and bear Jesus, the Son of God.
Mary's 'yes' to God's planher 'fiat'made possible the Incarnation of the Word.
This feast is celebrated exactly nine months before Christmas and is one of the most important feasts in the Church.

03-26.name: Saint Ludger
03-26.description: Bishop, missionary to Saxons and Frisians.
biography: Ludger was born in Frisia (Netherlands) around 744 and was educated at Utrecht under Saint Gregory.
He was ordained and worked as a missionary in Frisia and Saxony, rebuilding churches destroyed by pagans.
Charlemagne appointed him first Bishop of Mnster in 804. He continued missionary work until his death in 809.

03-27.name: Saint John Damascene (John of Damascus)
03-27.description: Priest, Doctor of the Church, defender of sacred images.
biography: John was born in Damascus around 676 into a Christian family serving the Muslim caliph.
He became a monk at Mar Saba monastery near Jerusalem and wrote extensively in defense of Christianity, especially against iconoclasm.
His works include 'The Fount of Knowledge' and beautiful hymns still used in Eastern liturgy. He died around 749.

03-28.name: Saint John of Capistrano
03-28.description: Franciscan priest, preacher, defender of Europe.
biography: John was born in Capistrano, Italy, in 1386. He studied law and was a governor but became a Franciscan at age 30 after imprisonment.
He became a great preacher, traveling throughout Europe. At age 70, he led a crusade that helped defeat the Ottoman Turks at Belgrade in 1456.
He died shortly after this victory and was canonized in 1690.

03-29.name: Saints Jonas and Barachisius
biography: Jonas and Barachisius were brothers who lived in Persia during the persecution of King Shapur II in the 4th century.
They were arrested for visiting and encouraging Christians in prison.
They were subjected to horrific tortures but refused to renounce their faith, dying as martyrs around 327 AD.

03-30.name: Saint John Climacus
03-30.description: Monk and abbot, author of 'The Ladder of Divine Ascent.'
biography: John was born around 579 and became a monk at Saint Catherine's Monastery on Mount Sinai at age 16.
He lived as a hermit for 40 years before being made abbot. He wrote 'The Ladder of Divine Ascent,' a spiritual classic describing 30 steps to holiness.
The work has been immensely influential in Eastern monasticism. He died around 649.

03-31.name: Saint Benjamin
biography: Benjamin was a deacon in Persia during the persecution of King Yazdegerd I in the early 5th century.
After a period of peace, he was arrested for refusing to stop preaching about Christ.
He was subjected to terrible tortures including sharp reeds driven under his nails, but remained faithful and died as a martyr around 424 AD.

04-01.name: Saint Hugh of Grenoble
04-01.description: Bishop of Grenoble, supporter of Saint Bruno and the Carthusians.
biography: Hugh was born in Dauphin, France, around 1053 into a noble family. He studied under Saint Hugh of Die.
Despite his youth and reluctance, he was made Bishop of Grenoble at age 27 and worked tirelessly to reform his diocese.
He gave Saint Bruno land to found the Grande Chartreuse monastery. He served as bishop for 52 years, dying in 1132.

04-02.name: Saint Francis of Paola
04-02.description: Founder of the Order of Minims, wonderworker.
biography: Francis was born in Paola, Calabria, in 1416 to parents who had prayed to Saint Francis for a child.
At age 14, he became a hermit living in a cave. Disciples joined him and he founded the Order of Minims ('the least'), known for humility and perpetual Lent.
He performed many miracles and was called to France by King Louis XI. He died in France in 1507, aged 91.

04-03.name: Saint Richard of Chichester
04-03.description: Bishop of Chichester, known for poverty and charity.
biography: Richard de Wych was born in Worcestershire around 1197. He studied at Oxford, Paris, and Bologna.
He became Chancellor of Oxford and later of Canterbury under Saint Edmund of Abingdon.
Elected Bishop of Chichester in 1245, he lived in great simplicity and defended Church rights. He died in 1253.

04-04.name: Saint Isidore of Seville
04-04.description: Archbishop, Doctor of the Church, last of the Latin Fathers.
biography: Isidore was born around 560 in Cartagena, Spain, to a family that produced four saints.
He succeeded his brother Saint Leander as Archbishop of Seville and worked to convert the Visigoths from Arianism.
He wrote the 'Etymologies,' an encyclopedia that preserved classical knowledge for the Middle Ages. He died in 636.

04-05.name: Saint Vincent Ferrer
04-05.description: Dominican priest, great preacher of penance.
biography: Vincent was born in Valencia, Spain, in 1350. He joined the Dominicans and became a renowned preacher.
He traveled throughout Europe preaching penance and announcing the Last Judgment, reportedly working countless miracles.
He helped end the Western Schism and converted thousands, including many Jews and Muslims. He died in Brittany in 1419.

04-06.name: Saint William of Eskill
biography: William was born in France and became a Cistercian monk and later abbot of Eskill in Denmark.
He worked to reform Danish monastic life according to strict Cistercian observance.
He died around 1203 and was greatly venerated in Scandinavia.

04-07.name: Saint Herman Joseph
04-07.description: Premonstratensian priest, mystic devoted to Mary.
biography: Herman was born in Cologne around 1150. From youth, he had great devotion to the Blessed Virgin Mary.
He joined the Premonstratensians and experienced mystical visions of Mary and the Christ Child.
He lived a life of prayer and simplicity, dying around 1241-1252.

04-08.name: Saint Dionysius of Corinth
04-08.description: Bishop of Corinth in the 2nd century.
biography: Dionysius was Bishop of Corinth in Greece during the late 2nd century.
He wrote many letters to various churches addressing doctrinal and disciplinary issues.
His writings were highly regarded in the early Church though most are now lost.

04-09.name: Saint Mary of Cleophas
04-09.description: One of the holy women at the Cross and tomb of Jesus.
biography: Mary of Cleophas was one of the women who stood by Jesus at His crucifixion.
She was present at Christ's tomb on Easter morning and was among the first to learn of His resurrection.
Tradition identifies her as the mother of the Apostles James the Less and Jude.

04-10.name: Saint Michael de Sanctis
biography: Michael Argemir was born in Catalonia, Spain, in 1591. He joined the Trinitarians at a young age.
He experienced mystical ecstasies, especially during Mass, and was known for his deep prayer life.
He died at age 35 in 1625 in Valladolid.

04-11.name: Saint Leo the Great
04-11.description: Pope, Doctor of the Church, defender of orthodox Christology.
biography: Leo became Pope in 440 and proved to be one of the greatest pontiffs in Church history.
At the Council of Chalcedon (451), his 'Tome' defined the two natures of Christ and was acclaimed as orthodox teaching.
He saved Rome from Attila the Hun through persuasion. He died in 461.

04-12.name: Saint Julius I
04-12.description: Pope, defender of Saint Athanasius and Nicene faith.
biography: Julius was elected Pope in 337 during the Arian controversy.
He staunchly defended Saint Athanasius and other bishops exiled by Arian emperors.
He worked to uphold the Nicene Creed and papal authority. He died in 352.

04-13.name: Saint Hermenegild
04-13.description: Visigothic prince, martyr for Catholic faith.
biography: Hermenegild was the son of King Leovigild of Spain, who was an Arian.
Through the influence of his wife and Saint Leander, Hermenegild converted to Catholicism.
His father demanded he return to Arianism. When he refused, he was imprisoned and killed in 586.

04-14.name: Saints Tiburtius, Valerian, and Maximus
04-14.description: Roman martyrs, related to Saint Cecilia.
biography: Valerian was the husband of Saint Cecilia who converted through her influence.
His brother Tiburtius also converted, and both buried martyred Christians.
They were arrested along with Maximus, an official who converted after witnessing their faith. All three were martyred around 230 AD.

04-15.name: Saint Paternus of Avranches
biography: Paternus was born in Brittany around 482. He lived as a hermit before being made Bishop of Avranches.
He evangelized the region and established monasteries.
He resigned his see to return to solitude and died around 565.

04-16.name: Saint Benedict Joseph Labre
04-16.description: Beggar, pilgrim saint, patron of homeless.
biography: Benedict Joseph was born in France in 1748. After being refused by several religious orders, he became a perpetual pilgrim.
He lived in complete poverty, making pilgrimages to major shrines across Europe.
He spent his last years in Rome, sleeping in the Colosseum and spending hours in prayer before the Blessed Sacrament. He died in 1783.

04-17.name: Saint Anicetus
04-17.description: Pope and martyr in the 2nd century.
biography: Anicetus was a Syrian who became Pope around 155 AD.
He received Saint Polycarp in Rome and discussed the Easter controversy charitably.
He opposed Gnosticism and tradition holds he was martyred around 166 AD.

04-18.name: Saint Apollonius the Apologist
biography: Apollonius was a learned Roman senator who lived in the 2nd century.
He was denounced as a Christian and brought before the Senate, where he delivered a brilliant defense of Christianity.
Despite his eloquent apology, he was condemned and beheaded around 185 AD.

04-19.name: Saint Expeditus
biography: Expeditus was a Roman centurion in Armenia who converted to Christianity.
When a crow cried 'Cras! Cras!' (Tomorrow! Tomorrow!), tempting him to delay his conversion, he killed it saying 'Hodie!' (Today!).
He was martyred for his faith around 303 AD during Diocletian's persecution.

04-20.name: Saint Agnes of Montepulciano
biography: Agnes was born near Montepulciano, Italy, in 1268. At age 9, she entered a convent.
She became abbess at age 15 and later founded a Dominican monastery.
She experienced mystical visions and worked miracles. She died in 1317 aged 49.

04-21.name: Saint Anselm of Canterbury
04-21.description: Archbishop, Doctor of the Church, Father of Scholasticism.
biography: Anselm was born in Aosta, Italy, in 1033. He became a Benedictine monk at Bec in Normandy.
As Archbishop of Canterbury (from 1093), he defended Church rights and suffered exile twice.
A brilliant theologian, he wrote the 'Proslogion' with its ontological argument for God. He died in 1109.

04-22.name: Saints Soter and Caius
biography: Soter was Pope from 166-175 AD, known for charity to persecuted Christians.
Caius was Pope from 283-296 AD during Diocletian's persecution.
Both are honored as martyrs for the faith.

04-23.name: Saint George
biography: George was a soldier in the Roman army during the reign of Emperor Diocletian in the late 3rd century.
When Diocletian began persecuting Christians, George openly declared his faith and criticized the persecution. He was tortured and executed around 303 AD.
The legend of George slaying a dragon became popular in the Middle Ages, symbolizing the victory of good over evil and faith over paganism.

04-24.name: Saint Fidelis of Sigmaringen
biography: Fidelis (born Mark Roy) was born in Germany in 1578. He practiced law before joining the Capuchins.
He was sent to preach to Protestants in Switzerland during the Thirty Years' War.
In 1622, he was killed by a mob while preaching, becoming a Counter-Reformation martyr.

04-25.name: Saint Mark the Evangelist
04-25.description: Evangelist, author of the second Gospel.
biography: Mark, also called John Mark, was a companion of Saint Peter and Saint Paul. He is believed to be the young man who fled naked when Jesus was arrested (Mark 14:51-52).
Tradition holds that Mark wrote his Gospel in Rome based on Saint Peter's preaching. His Gospel is the shortest and emphasizes Jesus's actions and miracles.
Mark founded the Church in Alexandria, Egypt, and became its first bishop. He was martyred there around 68 AD.

04-26.name: Saints Cletus and Marcellinus
biography: Cletus (Anacletus) was Pope from 76-88 AD, third successor of Peter.
Marcellinus was Pope from 296-304 AD during Diocletian's persecution.
Both are venerated as martyrs for the faith.

04-27.name: Saint Peter Canisius
04-27.description: Jesuit priest, Doctor of the Church, Second Apostle of Germany.
biography: Peter was born in the Netherlands in 1521 and joined the Jesuits in 1543.
He worked in Germany during the Counter-Reformation, founding colleges and writing influential catechisms.
His catechisms had over 400 editions. He died in Switzerland in 1597.

04-28.name: Saint Paul of the Cross
biography: Paul Danei was born in Italy in 1694. After a mystical experience, he founded the Passionists in 1720.
The order focuses on Christ's Passion and promoting devotion to His sufferings.
He preached throughout Italy and died in Rome in 1775.
attributes: Passionist habit with heart and cross

04-29.name: Saint Peter of Verona (Peter Martyr)
biography: Peter was born to Cathar parents in Verona in 1205 but converted to Catholicism.
He joined the Dominicans and became a famous preacher and inquisitor against heretics.
In 1252, he was assassinated by Cathars. His last words, written in blood, were 'Credo.'

04-30.name: Saint Catherine of Siena
04-30.description: Dominican tertiary, Doctor of the Church, mystic, reformer.
biography: Catherine was born in Siena in 1347, 24th of 25 children. She became a Dominican tertiary at 16.
She experienced visions and received the stigmata. She convinced Pope Gregory XI to return from Avignon to Rome.
Her 'Dialogue' and letters are spiritual classics. She died in 1380 aged 33 and was made Doctor of the Church in 1970.

05-01.name: Saint Joseph the Worker
05-01.description: Feast honoring Saint Joseph as patron of workers.
biography: This feast was instituted by Pope Pius XII in 1955 to honor Saint Joseph as the model and patron of workers.
As a carpenter, Joseph exemplified the dignity of work and provided for his family through honest labor.
The feast counteracts secular May Day celebrations and emphasizes the Christian understanding of work as participation in God's creative activity.

05-02.name: Saint of May 02
05-02.description: Various saints and martyrs commemorated on this day.
biography: On this day, the Church commemorates various saints and martyrs who gave witness to their faith.
Many local and lesser-known saints are celebrated on this day in different regions and traditions.
The communion of saints reminds us of the countless holy men and women throughout history.

06-24.name: Nativity of Saint John the Baptist
06-24.description: Birth of the Forerunner of Christ.
biography: John the Baptist was born to Zechariah and Elizabeth, an elderly couple who had been childless. His birth was announced by the Angel Gabriel.
John was chosen before birth to prepare the way for the Messiah. He lived as an ascetic in the desert and preached repentance.
He baptized Jesus in the Jordan River and proclaimed Him the Lamb of God. He was beheaded by Herod Antipas around 30 AD.

06-29.name: Saints Peter and Paul, Apostles
06-29.description: The two great Apostles, pillars of the Church.
biography: Peter was a fisherman called by Jesus to be the rock upon which He would build His Church. He was the leader of the Apostles and the first Pope.
Paul, originally Saul of Tarsus, was a persecutor of Christians until his dramatic conversion. He became the great Apostle to the Gentiles.
Tradition holds that both were martyred in Rome under Emperor Nero around 64-67 AD: Peter by crucifixion (upside down) and Paul by beheading.
patronage: Peter: Fishermen, papacy; Paul: Missionaries, writers, theologians

07-22.name: Saint Mary Magdalene
07-22.description: Apostle to the Apostles, first witness of the Resurrection.
biography: Mary Magdalene was from Magdala on the Sea of Galilee. Jesus cast seven demons out of her, and she became one of His most devoted followers.
She was present at the Crucifixion and burial of Jesus. On Easter morning, she was the first to see the Risen Christ, earning her the title 'Apostle to the Apostles.'
According to tradition, she later traveled to southern France as a missionary, spending her final years as a hermit in a cave.

07-25.name: Saint James the Greater, Apostle
07-25.description: Apostle, first apostolic martyr, patron of Spain.
biography: James was the son of Zebedee and brother of John the Evangelist. He was one of the first disciples called by Jesus and part of His inner circle.
He witnessed the Transfiguration and the Agony in the Garden. He was beheaded by King Herod Agrippa around 44 AD, becoming the first apostle to be martyred.
Tradition holds that his remains were translated to Santiago de Compostela in Spain, which became one of Christianity's greatest pilgrimage sites.

08-10.name: Saint Lawrence
biography: Lawrence was one of the seven deacons of Rome under Pope Sixtus II. He was in charge of the Church's treasury and distribution to the poor.
When Emperor Valerian ordered the Church to hand over its treasures, Lawrence distributed everything to the poor and presented them to the prefect, saying 'These are the treasures of the Church.'
For this act, he was martyred by being roasted alive on a gridiron in 258 AD. He is said to have joked with his executioners, saying 'Turn me over, I'm done on this side.'

08-15.name: Assumption of the Blessed Virgin Mary
08-15.description: Mary's assumption body and soul into heaven.
biography: The Assumption celebrates the belief that Mary, at the end of her earthly life, was taken up body and soul into heavenly glory.
This dogma was officially defined by Pope Pius XII in 1950, though it had been believed from ancient times.
The Assumption affirms Mary's unique role in salvation history and her perfect holiness, free from sin and its consequences.

09-29.name: Saints Michael, Gabriel, and Raphael, Archangels
09-29.description: The three archangels named in Scripture.
biography: Michael is the warrior angel who cast Satan from heaven. His name means 'Who is like God?' He is the protector of the Church and leader of the angelic hosts.
Gabriel is the messenger angel who announced to Mary that she would bear the Messiah. His name means 'Strength of God.'
Raphael is the healing angel who accompanied Tobias in the Book of Tobit. His name means 'God heals.'
attributes: Michael: Armor, sword, scales, dragon; Gabriel: Lily, scroll; Raphael: Staff, fish
patronage: Michael: Police, military; Gabriel: Messengers, postal workers; Raphael: Travelers, physicians

10-02.name: The Holy Guardian Angels
10-02.description: Feast of the angels assigned to guide and protect each person.
biography: The Church teaches that God assigns each person a guardian angel from birth to death.
These angels guide us toward good, help us avoid evil, and present our prayers to God.
Devotion to the guardian angels has been part of Christian tradition since ancient times, based on Scripture and the Church Fathers.

10-04.name: Saint Francis of Assisi
10-04.description: Founder of the Franciscan Order, lover of poverty and nature.
biography: Francis was born into a wealthy merchant family in Assisi, Italy, in 1181. After a worldly youth, he experienced a conversion and embraced radical poverty.
He rebuilt several ruined churches, gathered disciples, and founded the Franciscan Order dedicated to poverty, preaching, and service.
He received the stigmata (wounds of Christ) in 1224 and is known for his love of nature, having preached to birds and tamed a wolf. He died in 1226.

10-07.name: Our Lady of the Rosary
10-07.description: Memorial of the Blessed Virgin Mary and the Rosary devotion.
biography: This feast commemorates the victory of the Christian fleet over the Turks at the Battle of Lepanto on October 7, 1571.
Pope Pius V attributed the victory to the prayers of those praying the Rosary throughout Europe.
The Rosary is a meditative prayer focusing on the mysteries of Christ's life through the eyes of Mary.

10-15.name: Saint Teresa of Avila
10-15.description: Virgin, Doctor of the Church, mystic and reformer.
biography: Teresa was born in Avila, Spain, in 1515 and entered the Carmelite Order at age 20.
She experienced profound mystical experiences and visions of Christ. She reformed the Carmelite Order, founding numerous convents of Discalced Carmelites.
Her spiritual writings, including 'The Interior Castle' and 'The Way of Perfection,' are classics of Christian mysticism. She died in 1582 and was declared a Doctor of the Church in 1970.

11-01.name: All Saints
11-01.description: Solemnity honoring all saints in heaven.
biography: All Saints' Day honors all the saints, both known and unknown, who have attained heaven.
This feast reminds us that holiness is the universal call for all Christians, not just for a select few.
It celebrates the communion of saints and the reality that countless holy people have gone before us into glory.

11-02.name: Commemoration of All the Faithful Departed
11-02.description: All Souls' Day - prayers for the dead.
biography: All Souls' Day is dedicated to praying for all the faithful departed, especially those in purgatory.
The practice of praying for the dead is ancient, based on the belief that our prayers can help souls being purified before entering heaven.
Saint Odilo of Cluny established this commemoration in the 10th century, and it spread throughout the Church.

11-30.name: Saint Andrew, Apostle
biography: Andrew was a fisherman and disciple of John the Baptist. When John pointed out Jesus, Andrew became the first to follow Him, earning him the title 'First-called.'
He brought his brother Simon Peter to Jesus. After Pentecost, tradition says he preached in Greece, Asia Minor, and possibly as far as Russia.
He was martyred in Patras, Greece, around 60 AD, crucified on an X-shaped cross, which is now called Saint Andrew's Cross.

12-06.name: Saint Nicholas
12-06.description: Bishop of Myra, wonderworker, patron of children.
biography: Nicholas was born in Patara (modern Turkey) around 270 AD to wealthy Christian parents. He became Bishop of Myra.
He was known for his generosity, especially to children and the poor. He secretly gave gold to save three poor girls from prostitution, throwing bags through their window.
He suffered persecution under Diocletian and attended the Council of Nicaea. He died around 343 AD. His generosity inspired the Santa Claus tradition.

12-07.name: Saint of December 07
12-07.description: Various saints and martyrs commemorated on this day.

12-08.name: Immaculate Conception of the Blessed Virgin Mary
12-08.description: Solemnity of Mary's conception without original sin.
biography: The Immaculate Conception celebrates the belief that Mary was preserved from original sin from the first moment of her conception.
This privilege was given to her in view of the merits of Jesus Christ, preparing her to be a worthy mother of God.
The dogma was officially defined by Pope Pius IX in 1854. This is the patronal feast of the United States.

12-25.name: Nativity of Our Lord Jesus Christ
12-25.description: Christmas - the birth of the Savior.
biography: Christmas celebrates the birth of Jesus Christ in Bethlehem around 4-6 BC, fulfilling Old Testament prophecies.
Jesus was born to the Virgin Mary in a stable because there was no room in the inn. Angels announced His birth to shepherds.
The Incarnation - God becoming man - is the central mystery of Christianity, celebrated with joy throughout the world.

12-26.name: Saint Stephen, First Martyr
biography: Stephen was one of seven deacons chosen by the Apostles to serve the early Church in Jerusalem.
He performed great wonders and signs among the people and preached powerfully about Jesus as the Messiah.
Around 34 AD, he was brought before the Sanhedrin, gave a bold testimony, and was stoned to death, becoming Christianity's first martyr. Saul (later Paul) witnessed his death.

12-27.name: Saint John, Apostle and Evangelist
12-27.description: Beloved disciple, author of the fourth Gospel.
biography: John, son of Zebedee and brother of James, was one of Jesus's closest disciples, part of the inner circle at the Transfiguration and Gethsemane.
At the Last Supper, he reclined next to Jesus. At the Cross, Jesus entrusted Mary to his care. He wrote the fourth Gospel, three epistles, and the Book of Revelation.
He lived to old age in Ephesus and died around 100 AD, the only apostle not martyred.

12-28.name: The Holy Innocents
12-28.description: Baby boys martyred by King Herod.
biography: The Holy Innocents were the male children of Bethlehem, two years old and under, killed by King Herod's order.
Herod, seeking to eliminate the newborn King of the Jews, ordered this massacre. The Holy Family escaped to Egypt.
These children are venerated as the first martyrs, having died in place of Christ.

12-29.name: Saint of December 29
12-29.description: Various saints and martyrs commemorated on this day.
biography: On this day, the Church commemorates various saints and martyrs who gave witness to their faith.

12-31.name: Saint Sylvester I
12-31.description: Saint Sylvester I was the 33rd Pope of the Catholic Church, serving from 314 to 335 AD. His pontificate coincided with the reign of Constantine the Great and the end of Christian persecution.
biography: Pope Sylvester I presided over the Church during a pivotal moment in Christian history. When Constantine the Great ended the persecution of Christians and granted freedom of worship, Sylvester guided the Church through this transformative period.

According to tradition, he baptized Emperor Constantine, though historical evidence suggests the emperor was baptized later by Eusebius of Nicomedia. Nevertheless, Sylvester's influence on Constantine and the early Christian church was profound.

During his papacy, the great basilicas of St. Peter and St. John Lateran were built in Rome. He also presided during the First Council of Nicaea in 325 AD, though he sent legates rather than attending himself.
attributes: Often shown with a bull or dragon

roman_1970.name: Roman Calendar 1970 (Paul VI)
roman_1970.description: Roman Missal according to the post-Vatican II reform (Novus Ordo).

01-01.name: Mary, Mother of God
01-01.description: Solemnity of the Blessed Virgin Mary as Theotokos (God-bearer).
biography: This solemnity celebrates Mary's divine motherhood, proclaimed at the Council of Ephesus in 431 AD.
The title 'Theotokos' (God-bearer) affirms that Mary is truly the Mother of God because Jesus is both fully human and fully divine.
This feast replaced the Circumcision of the Lord on January 1 after the 1969 liturgical reforms, though it keeps the octave day of Christmas.

01-02.name: Saints Basil the Great and Gregory Nazianzen
01-02.description: Bishops and Doctors of the Church, Cappadocian Fathers.
biography: These two great Church Fathers are celebrated together in the post-Vatican II calendar.
Basil (329-379) and Gregory (329-390) were close friends who studied together in Athens and both became bishops and theologians.
They defended orthodox Christianity against Arianism and made significant contributions to Trinitarian theology and Christian spirituality.

01-03.name: Most Holy Name of Jesus (optional)
01-03.description: Optional memorial of the Holy Name.
biography: This optional memorial celebrates the holy name of Jesus, given to Him at His circumcision.
The name Jesus means 'God saves' and was commanded by the angel Gabriel before His birth.
Devotion to the Holy Name was promoted by Saints Bernardine of Siena and John of Capistrano.

01-04.name: Saint Elizabeth Ann Seton
01-04.description: Religious founder, first native-born American saint.
biography: Elizabeth Ann Bayley Seton (1774-1821) was the first person born in the United States to be canonized.
A convert from Episcopalianism, she founded the Sisters of Charity and established the Catholic school system in America.
She was canonized in 1975 by Pope Paul VI.

01-05.name: Saint John Neumann
biography: John Neumann (1811-1860) emigrated from Bohemia and became Bishop of Philadelphia.
He organized the first diocesan Catholic school system in the United States.
He was canonized in 1977 by Pope Paul VI.

01-06.name: Epiphany of the Lord
01-06.description: Solemnity of the manifestation of Christ to the nations.
biography: The Epiphany celebrates Christ's manifestation to the Gentiles through the visit of the Magi.
In some countries, this solemnity is transferred to the Sunday between January 2 and 8.
It marks the end of the Christmas season and begins the period of Ordinary Time.

01-07.name: Saint Raymond of Penyafort
biography: Raymond (1175-1275) was a Dominican priest and expert in canon law.
He compiled the Decretals for Pope Gregory IX, which became the standard collection of canon law.
He lived to be 100 years old and worked for the conversion of Muslims and Jews.

01-08.name: Saint of January 08
biography: The Roman Calendar celebrates various saints and memorials on this day.
Some feasts are obligatory memorials while others are optional.
Local calendars may celebrate additional saints particular to their region.

12-31.name: Saint Sylvester I
12-31.description: Pope and confessor (optional memorial in 1970 calendar).
biography: Saint Sylvester I was Pope from 314 to 335 AD, during the pivotal era when Constantine ended Christian persecution.
His pontificate saw the construction of the great Roman basilicas and coincided with the Council of Nicaea.
Though celebrated on December 31 in both calendars, it's an optional memorial in the post-Vatican II calendar.

orthodox.name: Orthodox Calendar
orthodox.description: Eastern Orthodox liturgical calendar following the Julian calendar tradition.

01-01.name: Circumcision of the Lord
01-01.description: Feast of the Circumcision of Christ.
biography: The Orthodox Church celebrates the Circumcision of the Lord on January 1 (December 19 Old Style).
This feast emphasizes Christ's obedience to the Law and His true humanity.
It is also the feast of Saint Basil the Great in the Orthodox tradition.

01-01.name: Saint Basil the Great
01-01.description: Archbishop of Caesarea, one of the Three Holy Hierarchs.
biography: Saint Basil is celebrated on January 1 in the Orthodox Church (along with the Circumcision).
He is one of the Three Holy Hierarchs, along with Gregory the Theologian and John Chrysostom.
His Divine Liturgy is celebrated on certain feast days in Eastern churches.

01-06.name: Theophany (Baptism of the Lord)
01-06.description: Feast of the Baptism of Christ in the Jordan.
biography: Theophany is one of the Great Feasts of the Orthodox Church, celebrating Christ's baptism.
The name means 'manifestation of God,' as the Holy Trinity was revealed at Christ's baptism.
It is celebrated with the Great Blessing of Waters, which is used throughout the year.

01-07.name: Synaxis of John the Baptist
01-07.description: Assembly in honor of the Forerunner.
biography: The day after Theophany, the Orthodox Church celebrates the Synaxis (Assembly) of John the Baptist.
This honors the Baptist's role in recognizing and baptizing Christ.
John is called the Forerunner and is highly venerated in Orthodox tradition.

01-02.name: Orthodox Saints of January 02
biography: The Orthodox Church commemorates various saints on this day.
The Orthodox calendar follows different traditions and may celebrate saints on different dates than the Western Church.
Many local and monastic saints are commemorated throughout the Orthodox world.

bonus.name: Bonus Saints and Feasts
bonus.description: Additional saints, local patrons, and lesser-known holy men and women.

02-29.name: Saint Augustus Chapdelaine
biography: Augustus Chapdelaine was born in France in 1814 and became a priest of the Paris Foreign Missions Society.
He was sent to China as a missionary in 1852 and worked among the poor in Guangxi province.
He was arrested, tortured, and executed in 1856 during anti-Christian persecutions. He was canonized in 2000.

12-25.name: Nativity of Our Lord Jesus Christ
12-25.description: Christmas - the birth of Jesus Christ.
biography: Christmas celebrates the birth of Jesus Christ in Bethlehem around 4-6 BC.
The word 'Christmas' comes from 'Christ's Mass,' celebrating the Incarnation of God.
This is the second most important feast in Christianity after Easter, celebrating God becoming man.

12-26.name: Saint Stephen, First Martyr
biography: Stephen was one of the seven deacons ordained by the Apostles to serve the early Church.
He was known for his wisdom, faith, and powerful preaching about Jesus as the Messiah.
He was stoned to death around 34 AD, becoming the first Christian martyr. Saul (later Paul) witnessed his martyrdom.

03-17.name: Saint Patrick
03-17.description: Apostle of Ireland, bishop and confessor.
biography: Patrick was born in Roman Britain around 385 and was captured by Irish raiders at age 16.
After six years as a slave shepherd, he escaped but later returned to Ireland as a missionary bishop.
He is credited with bringing Christianity to Ireland and using the shamrock to explain the Trinity.

10-31.name: Vigil of All Saints
biography: The evening before All Saints' Day (November 1) has been celebrated since ancient times.
The name 'Halloween' comes from 'All Hallows' Eve,' the vigil of All Saints.
It was traditionally a time of prayer and preparation for honoring all the saints.

11-01.name: All Saints
11-01.description: Solemnity honoring all known and unknown saints.
biography: All Saints' Day honors all the saints, known and unknown, who have attained heaven.
This feast has been celebrated since the 4th century and was fixed to November 1 by Pope Gregory III.
It reminds us that holiness is the universal call for all Christians.

11-02.name: All Souls' Day
11-02.description: Commemoration of all the faithful departed.
biography: All Souls' Day is dedicated to praying for all the faithful departed, especially those in purgatory.
This commemoration was established by Saint Odilo of Cluny in the 10th century.
Catholics offer Masses, prayers, and alms for the repose of the souls of the deceased.

01-01.name: Additional Saints of January 01
biography: Many local, regional, and lesser-known saints are celebrated on this day.
These include martyrs, confessors, and holy men and women from various times and places.
Each local church and religious order may have particular saints they commemorate.
